standard_metadata.standard_description: Compare two decimals to thousandths based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

hints.content: ### Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  >$\begin{align}\greenD{\text{0.26}} ~~ &\square ~~\blueD{\text{206 thousandths}}\\ \\ \greenD{0.26} ~~&\square~~\blueD{0.206}\\ \end{align}$

### Comparing with a place value table  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\greenD0$ | . | $\greenD2$| $\greenD6$ | $0$ $\blueD0$| $.$ | $\blueD2$ | $\blueD0$ | $\blueD6$    $\greenD{0.26}>\blueD{0.206}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
### The answer  $0.26>206$ thousandths

### Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  >$\begin{align}\greenD{\left(6\times1\right)+\left(1\times\dfrac1{100}\right)} ~~ &\square ~~\blueD{6.1}\\ \\ \greenD{6+0.01} ~~&\square~~\blueD{6.1}\\ \\ \greenD{6.01} ~~&\square~~\blueD{6.1} \end{align}$

### Comparing with a place value table  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\greenD6$ | . | $\greenD0$| $\greenD1$  $\blueD6$| $.$ | $\blueD1$ | $0$   $\greenD{6.01}<\blueD{6.1}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
### The answer  $\left(6\times1\right)+\left(1\times\dfrac1{100}\right)<6.1$

### Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  >$\begin{align}\greenD{\text{0.085}} ~~ &\square ~~\blueD{\text{85 thousandths}}\\ \\ \greenD{0.085} ~~&\square~~\blueD{0.085}\\ \end{align}$
### Compare  $\greenD{0.085}=\blueD{0.085}$
### The answer  $0.085=85 \text { thousandths}$

### Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  >$\begin{align}\greenD{\left(5\times\dfrac1{10}\right)+\left(9\times\dfrac1{100}\right)} ~~ &\square ~~\blueD{5.9}\\ \\ \greenD{0.5+0.09} ~~&\square~~\blueD{5.9}\\ \\ \greenD{0.59} ~~&\square~~\blueD{5.9} \end{align}$

### Comparing with a place value table  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\greenD0$ | . | $\greenD5$| $\greenD9$  $\blueD5$| $.$ | $\blueD9$ | $0$  $\greenD{0.59}<\blueD{5.9}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
### The answer  $\left(5\times\dfrac1{10}\right)+\left(9\times\dfrac1{100}\right)<5.9$

### Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  >$\begin{align}\greenD{\text{0.7}} ~~ &\square ~~\blueD{{7 \times \dfrac1{100}}}\\ \\ \greenD{0.7} ~~&\square~~\blueD{0.07}\\ \end{align}$

### Comparing with a place value table  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\greenD0$ | . | $\greenD7$| $0$  $\blueD0$| $.$ | $\blueD0$ | $\blueD7$  $\greenD{0.7}>\blueD{0.07}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
### The answer  $0.7>7 \times \dfrac1{100}$

question.content: **Select two values that can replace $\square$ to  make the inequality true.**  $5.436<\square$

hints.content: ### Is $\blueD{4 + 0.8 + 0.03}$ a correct answer?  $\blueD{4 + 0.8 + 0.03} = \blueD{4.83}$  | | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\goldD{5.436}$ | = |$\goldD5$ | . | $\goldD4$| $\goldD3$ | $\goldD6$ $\blueD{4.83}$ | = | $\blueD4$ | . |$\blueD8$|  $\blueD3$ | $0$     $\goldD{5.436}\redD>\blueD{4.83}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

### Is $\purpleC{5.099}$ a correct answer?  |  | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\goldD{5.436}$ | = |$\goldD5$ | . | $\goldD4$| $\goldD3$ | $\goldD6$  $\purpleC{5.099}$ | =  |$\purpleC5$ | . | $\purpleC0$| $\purpleC9$ | $\purpleC9$  $\goldD{5.436}\redD>\purpleC{5.099}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

### Is $\maroonD{5\text{ ones and }} \maroonD{8{\text{ tenths}}}$ a correct answer?  $\maroonD{5\text{ ones and }} \maroonD{8{\text{ tenths}}} = \maroonD{5.8}$  | | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  $\goldD{5.436}$ | = | $\goldD5$ | . | $\goldD4$| $\goldD3$ | $\goldD6$ $\maroonD{5.8}$ | =  |$\maroonD5$ | . | $\maroonD8$| $0$ | $0$  $\goldD{5.436}\greenD<\maroonD{5.8}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

### Is $\tealD{(7\times1)+\left ( 7\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )+\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$ a correct answer?  $\tealD{(7\times1)+\left ( 7\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )+\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \tealD{7.76}$  | | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  $\goldD{5.436}$ | = | $\goldD5$ | . | $\goldD4$| $\goldD3$ | $\goldD6$ $\tealD{7.76}$ | =  |$\tealD7$ | . | $\tealD7$| $\tealD6$ | $0$  $\goldD{5.436}\greenD<\tealD{7.76}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

###The answers  The following values make the inequality true:  - $\maroonD{5\text{ ones and }} \maroonD{8{\text{ tenths}}}$  - $\tealD{(7\times1)+\left ( 7\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )+\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$

question.content: **Select two values that can replace $\square$ to  make the equation true.**  $\square=5.040$

hints.content: Let's solve to get each answer choice into standard form:  $\begin{align} &\maroonD{\text{Five ones and forty thousandths}} = \maroonD{5.040}\\\\ &\purpleC{50 + 0.40} = \purpleC{50.40}\\\\ &\tealD{(5\times1)+\left ( 4\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \tealD{5.04} \end{align}$

###Compare with a place value chart  Let's use a place value chart to see which numbers are equal to $\goldD{5.040}$.  | | Tens |  Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\goldD{5.040}$ | = | $0$   | $\goldD5$ | . | $\goldD0$| $\goldD4$ | $\goldD0$ $\blueD{5.4}$ | = |  $0$ | $\blueD5$ | . |$\blueD4$|  $0$ | $0$ $\tealD{5.04}$ | = |$0$| $\tealD5$ | . | $\tealD0$| $\tealD4$ | $0$ $\purpleC{50.40}$ | = | $\purpleC5$ | $\purpleC0$ | . | $\purpleC4$| $\purpleC0$ |$0$ $\maroonD{5.04}$ | = |  $0$ | $\maroonD5$ | . | $\maroonD0$| $\maroonD4$ |  $0$
Which numbers have the same digits in every place value as $\goldD{5.040}$?
###The answer  - $\maroonD{\text{Five ones and forty thousandths}} = \goldD{5.040}$  - $\tealD{(5\times1)+\left ( 4\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \goldD{5.040}$

question.content: **Select two values that can replace $\square$ to  make the inequality true.**  $\square<32.6$

hints.content: ### Is $\blueD{3\text{ tens} + 2\text{ ones} + 6\text{ tenths} + 1\text{ hundredth}}$  a correct answer?  $\blueD{3\text{ tens} + 2\text{ ones} + 6\text{ tenths} + 1\text{ hundredth}} = \blueD{32.61}$  | | Tens | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\blueD{32.16}$ | = | $\blueD3$ |$\blueD2$ | . |$\blueD6$|  $\blueD1$ $\goldD{32.6}$ | = | $\goldD3$ |$\goldD2$ | . | $\goldD6$| $0$  $\blueD{32.61}\redD>\goldD{32.6}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

### Is $\purpleC{20 + 6 + 0.3}$ a correct answer?  $\purpleC{20 + 6 + 0.3} = \purpleC{26.3}$  | | Tens | Ones | .| Tenths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\purpleC{26.3}$ | = | $\purpleC2$ |$\purpleC6$ | . |$\purpleC3$   $\goldD{32.6}$ | = | $\goldD3$ |$\goldD2$ | . | $\goldD6$  $\purpleC{26.3}\greenD<\goldD{32.6}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

### Is $\tealD{(3\times10) + (5\times1) +\left ( 1\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right ) + \left ( 6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$  a correct answer?  $\tealD{(3\times10) + (5\times1) +\left ( 1\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right ) + \left ( 6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \tealD{35.16}$  | | Tens | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\tealD{35.16}$ | = | $\tealD3$ |$\tealD5$ | . |$\tealD1$|  $\tealD6$ $\goldD{32.6}$ | = | $\goldD3$ |$\goldD2$ | . | $\goldD6$| $0$  $\tealD{35.16}\redD>\goldD{32.6}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

### Is $\maroonD{30.26}$ a correct answer?  | | Tens | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\maroonD{30.26}$ | = | $\maroonD3$ |$\maroonD0$ | . |$\maroonD2$|  $\maroonD6$ $\goldD{32.6}$ | = | $\goldD3$ |$\goldD2$ | . | $\goldD6$| $0$  $\maroonD{30.26}\greenD<\goldD{32.6}$    [[☃ explanation 2]]
###The answers  The following values make the inequality true:  - $\purpleC{20 + 6 + 0.3}$  - $\maroonD{30.26}$

question.content: **Select two values that can replace $\square$ to  make the equation true.**  $4.7=\square$

hints.content: Let's solve to get each answer choice into standard form:  $\begin{align} &\maroonD{(4\times1)+\left ( 7\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \maroonD{4.07}\\\\ &\purpleC{4 + 0.70} = \purpleC{4.70}\\\\ &\blueD{\text{Seven ones and four tenths}} = \blueD{7.4} \end{align}$

###Compare with a place value chart  Let's use a place value chart to see which numbers are equal to $\goldD{4.7}$.  | | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\goldD{4.7}$ | = | $\goldD4$ | . | $\goldD7$| $0$  $\maroonD{4.07}$ | = | $\maroonD4$ | . | $\maroonD0$| $\maroonD7$ $\purpleC{4.70}$ | = | $\purpleC4$ | . | $\purpleC7$| $\purpleC0$  $\blueD{7.4}$ | = | $\blueD7$ | . |$\blueD4$|  $0$ $\tealD{4.70}$ | = | $\tealD4$ | . | $\tealD7$| $\tealD0$
Which numbers have the same digits in every place value as $\goldD{4.7}$ ?
###The answer  - $\goldD{4.7} = \purpleC{4 + 0.70}$  - $\goldD{4.7} = \tealD{4.70}$

question.content: **Select two values that can replace $\square$ to  make the inequality true.**  $\square>8.109$

hints.content: ### Is $\blueD{(9\times1)+\left ( 1\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )+\left (8\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$ a correct answer?  $\blueD{(9\times1)+\left ( 1\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )+\left (8\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}=\blueD{9.18}$   | | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\blueD{9.18}$ | = | $\blueD9$ | . |$\blueD1$|  $\blueD8$ | $0$ $\goldD{8.109}$ | = | $\goldD8$ | . | $\goldD1$| $\goldD0$ |$\goldD9$  $\blueD{9.18}\greenD>\goldD{8.109}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

### Is $\purpleC{8.099}$ a correct answer?  | | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\purpleC{8.099}$ | = | $\purpleC8$ | . |$\purpleC0$|  $\purpleC9$ | $\purpleC9$ $\goldD{8.109}$ | = | $\goldD8$ | . | $\goldD1$| $\goldD0$ |$\goldD9$  $\purpleC{8.099}\redD<\goldD{8.109}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

### Is $\maroonD{\text{eight ones and ninety-one hundredths}}$ a correct answer?  $\maroonD{\text{Eight ones and ninety-one hundredths}} = \maroonD{8.91}$  | | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\maroonD{8.91}$ | = | $\maroonD8$ | . |$\maroonD9$|  $\maroonD1$ | $0$ $\goldD{8.109}$ | = | $\goldD8$ | . | $\goldD1$| $\goldD0$ |$\goldD9$  $\maroonD{8.91}\greenD>\goldD{8.109}$    [[☃ explanation 2]]

### Is $\tealD{8\text{ ones} + 19\text{ thousandths}}$ a correct answer?  $\tealD{8\text{ ones} + 19\text{ thousandths}} = \tealD{8.019}$  | | Ones | .| Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  :-: | :-: $\tealD{8.019}$ | = | $\tealD8$ | . |$\tealD0$|  $\tealD1$ | $\tealD9$ $\goldD{8.109}$ | = | $\goldD8$ | . | $\goldD1$| $\goldD0$ |$\goldD9$  $\tealD{8.019}\redD<\goldD{8.109}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]

###The answers  The following values make the inequality true:  - $\blueD{(9\times1)+\left ( 1\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )+\left (8\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$  - $\maroonD{\text{Eight ones and ninety-one hundredths}}$

question.content: **Order the values from least to greatest.**   *Put the lowest value at the top.*

hints.content: ###Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  $\purpleC{0.88}=\purpleC{0.88}$  ${\blueD{\left(8\times\dfrac1{100}\right)}}=\blueD{0.08}$  $\text{\greenD{8 tens}}=\greenD{80}$

###Comparing with a place value chart  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Tens | Ones | . | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |:-: |:-: $0$| $\purpleC0$ | . | $\purpleC8$ | $\purpleC8$  $0$ |$\blueD0$ | . |  $\blueD0$ | $\blueD8$  $\greenD8$ |$\greenD0$ | . | $0$ | $0$
$\blueD{0.08}<\purpleC{0.88}<\greenD{80}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]
###The answer  The values from least to greatest:  ${\blueD{\left(8\times\dfrac1{100}\right)}},\purpleC{0.88}, \text{\greenD{8 tens}}$

question.content: **Order the values from least to greatest.**

hints.content: ###Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  $\purpleC{\left(3\times\dfrac1{100}\right)+\left(3\times\dfrac1{1000}\right)}=\purpleC{0.03+0.003}=\purpleC{0.033}$  $\text{\blueD{3 tenths}}=\blueD{0.3}$  $\text{\greenD{0.03}}=\greenD{0.03}$

###Comparing with a place value chart  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Ones | . | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |:-: $\purpleC0$ | . | $\purpleC0$ | $\purpleC3$  | $\purpleC3$ $\blueD0$ | . |  $\blueD3$ | $0$ | $0$ $\greenD0$ | . | $\greenD0$ | $\greenD3$ | $0$
$\greenD{0.03}<\purpleC{0.033}<\blueD{0.3}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]
###The answer  The values from least to greatest:  $  \text{\greenD{0.03}},\purpleC{\left(3\times\dfrac1{100}\right)+\left(3\times\dfrac1{1000}\right)}, \text{\blueD{3 tenths}}$

question.content: **Order the values from least to greatest.**

hints.content: ###Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  $\purpleC{(6\times1)+\left(7\times\dfrac1{100}\right)}=\purpleC{6+0.07}=\purpleC{6.07}$  $\blueD{67\text{ hundredths}}=\blueD{0.67}$  $\text{\greenD{6.7}}=\greenD{6.7}$

###Comparing with a place value chart  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Ones | . | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |:-: |:-: $\purpleC6$ | . | $\purpleC0$ | $\purpleC7$  $\blueD0$ | . |  $\blueD6$ | $\blueD7$  $\greenD6$ | . | $\greenD7$ | $0$
$\blueD{0.67}<\purpleC{6.07}<\greenD{6.7}$    [[☃ explanation 1]]
###The answer  The values from least to greatest:  $\blueD{67\text{ hundredths}},\purpleC{(6\times1)+\left(7\times\dfrac1{100}\right)}, \text{\greenD{6.7}}$

question.content: **Order the values from least to greatest.**

hints.content: ###Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  $\purpleC{91\text{ hundredths}}=\purpleC{0.91}$  $\blueD{0.19}=\blueD{0.19}$  ${\greenD{(1\times1)+\left(9\times\dfrac1{10}\right)}}=\greenD{1+0.9}=\greenD{1.9}$

###Comparing with a place value chart  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Ones | . | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |:-: |:-: $\purpleC0$ | . | $\purpleC9$ | $\purpleC1$  $\blueD0$ | . |  $\blueD1$ | $\blueD9$  $\greenD1$ | . | $\greenD9$ | $0$
$\blueD{0.19}<\purpleC{0.91}<\greenD{1.9}$     [[☃ explanation 2]]
###The answer  The values from least to greatest:  $\blueD{0.19},\purpleC{91\text { hundredths}}, {\greenD{(1\times1)+\left(9\times\dfrac1{10}\right)}}$

question.content: **Order the values from least to greatest.**

hints.content: ###Getting started  Let's rewrite each value in standard form:  $\purpleC{5}=\purpleC{5}$  $\blueD{5\text{ hundredths}}=\blueD{0.05}$  ${\greenD{(5\times10)+\left(5\times\dfrac1{10}\right)}}=\greenD{50+0.5}=\greenD{50.5}$

###Comparing with a place value chart  Now, we can use a place value chart to compare the numbers.  Tens | Ones | . | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |:-: |:-: $0$| $\purpleC5$ | . | $0$ | $0$  $0$ |$\blueD0$ | . |  $\blueD0$ | $\blueD5$  $\greenD5$ |$\greenD0$ | . | $\greenD5$ | $0$
$\blueD{0.05}<\purpleC{5}<\greenD{50.5}$     [[☃ explanation 2]]
###The answer  The values from least to greatest:  $\blueD{5\text{ hundredths}},\purpleC{5}, {\greenD{(5\times10)+\left(5\times\dfrac1{10}\right)}}$
